questions.question_text: Which of the following types of RAID is also known as disk striping?

discussion.content: RAID 0 RAID 0 is known as disk striping. It splits data into chunks and writes them across multiple disks, improving performance by allowing simultaneous read and write operations across the disks. However, RAID 0 does not provide redundancy, meaning if one disk fails, all data is lost.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a process of transformation where the old system can no longer be maintained?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A crisis is a turning point, a crucial moment that demands immediate attention and action. When a system reaches a point where it can no longer be maintained, it often signifies a crisis.

Selected Answer: A
When a disaster occurs, it can cause significant damage to the existing system, rendering it unusable or difficult to maintain. In such cases, it may be necessary to initiate a process of transformation to replace the old system with a new one that is better suited to meet the current needs and requirements. This process of transformation may involve a complete overhaul of the existing system, including hardware, software, and processes, and can be complex and time-consuming.

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of RAID offers no protection for the parity disk?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Among the options provided, RAID 5 (option C) offers no protection for the parity disk. In a RAID 5 setup, parity information is distributed among all the disks in the array. If two disks fail simultaneously, data will be lost, including parity data, which cannot be recovered.

Selected Answer: B
Raid 1 doesnt have parity

Selected Answer: D
The only RAID that don't have parity protection but uses a parity disk is RAID3, RAID 1 don't use parity disk and RAID5 writes parity in all disks except one, so if a disk fails the parity is rebuilt, therefore has a protection. The only answer that uses parity but is not protected is RAID3, if parity disk fails there's no protection to recover parity bits. questions.question_text:
Adam works as a Professional Penetration Tester. A project has been assigned to him to test the vulnerabilities of the CISCO Router of Umbrella Inc. Adam finds out that HTTP Configuration Arbitrary Administrative Access Vulnerability exists in the router. By applying different password cracking tools, Adam gains access to the router. He analyzes the router config file and notices the following lines: logging buffered errors logging history critical logging trap warnings logging 10.0.1.103
By analyzing the above lines, Adam concludes that this router is logging at log level 4 to the syslog server 10.0.1.103. He decides to change the log level from 4 to
0.
Which of the following is the most likely reason of changing the log level?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Router messages

0 Emergencies System shutting down due to missing fan tray
1 Alerts Temperature limit exceeded
2 Critical Memory allocation failures
3 Errors Interface Up/Down messages
4 Warnings Configuration file written to server, via SNMP request
5 Notifications Line protocol Up/Down
6 Information Access-list violation logging
7 Debugging Debug messages

Referencies: https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-knowledge-base/how-to-configure-logging-in-cisco-ios/ta-p/3132434

choices.B: By changing the log level, Adam can easily perform a SQL injection attack.
choices.A: Changing the log level from 4 to 0 will result in the logging of only emergencies. This way the modification in the router is not sent to the syslog server.
choices.D: Changing the log level from 4 to 0 will result in the termination of logging. This way the modification in the router is not sent to the syslog server.
choices.C: Changing the log level grants access to the router as an Administrator.

questions.answer_description:
The Router Log Level directive is used by the sys log server to specify the level of severity of the log. This directive is used to control the types of errors that are sent to the error log by constraining the severity level. Eight different levels are present in the Log Level directive, which are shown below in order of their descending significance:

Number Level Description -
0emergEmergencies - system is unusable
1alertAction must be taken immediately
2critCritical Conditions
3errorError conditions
4warnWarning conditions
5notice Normal but significant condition
6infoInformational
7debug Debug-level messages
Note: When a certain level is specified, the messages from all other levels of higher significance will also be reported. For example, when Log Level crit is specified, then messages with log levels of alert and emerg will also be reported.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The backup is only used when data is already lost or damaged, i think the answer that best fit is update AV frequently. ChatGPT says that all options are correct, but if one have to be chosen, would be option B

questions.answer_description: Updating the anti-virus software regularly is the best way of protecting important data against virus attack.
